title: 115_hr3715
content: The Act titled "Scenic Columbia Gorge Restoration Act of 2017" allows for expedited recovery activities in response to catastrophic events in national scenic areas. The Act defines a catastrophic event as any natural disaster or fire, flood, or explosion. It also includes containment of the event before its actual end. The term "conclusion" in relation to a catastrophic event includes containment of the event before its actual end. A National Scenic Area is an area of the National Forest System designated for its natural, scenic, and recreational values. Response activity refers to salvage or reforestation operations within a National Scenic Area. Response activity refers to salvage or reforestation operations within a National Scenic Area, with the Secretary of Agriculture overseeing prompt proposal of these activities within 30 days of a catastrophic event. The Secretary of Agriculture, through the Chief of the Forest Service, must propose response activities for lands impacted by a catastrophic event within a National Scenic Area within 30 days. Public input and objection filing periods are also specified. The Secretary must allow public input and objection filing periods for response activities in a National Scenic Area, with specific timeframes. Upon completion of the process, the Secretary will implement the response activity. An expedited environmental assessment is required, with exceptions. The Secretary will implement response activities in a National Scenic Area, with an expedited environmental assessment required within 60 days after a catastrophic event. A categorical exclusion is available for certain response activities. Response activities in a National Scenic Area must be completed within 60 days after a catastrophic event. A categorical exclusion is available for response activities not exceeding 10,000 acres within the area, including visible lands from key viewing areas and those providing screening for human development. Response activities in a National Scenic Area must be completed within 60 days after a catastrophic event. A categorical exclusion is available for activities not exceeding 10,000 acres, including visible lands from key viewing areas, screening for human development, municipal watersheds, and utility or power transmission right-of-ways. Consultation under the Endangered Species Act is required if the activity may adversely affect a listed species or critical habitat. Consultation under the Endangered Species Act is not required if a response activity is not likely to harm a listed species or critical habitat. Expedited consultation is available for activities not covered by the previous provision. Expedited consultation under the Endangered Species Act must be concluded within 90 days of the request by the Secretary for response activities not covered by the initial provision. Expedited consultation under the Endangered Species Act must be concluded within 90 days of the request by the Secretary. If the consultation is not concluded within this period, the response activity may proceed without violating the Endangered Species Act. Expedited consultation under the Endangered Species Act must be concluded within 90 days of the request by the Secretary. If not concluded within this period, the response activity may proceed without violating the Act. No court can issue restraining orders, injunctions, or injunctions pending appeal regarding the response activity. Section 705 of title 5, United States Code, does not apply to challenges to the response activity. (g) Funding Source.--Amounts in the special fund established pursuant to the Knutson-Vandenberg Act shall be available to the Secretary for response activities, including reforestation on National Scenic Area lands impacted by catastrophic events. The Secretary shall achieve reforestation of at least 75 percent of National Scenic Area lands impacted by a catastrophic event within two years.
